review: Like most people said this is not for those who dont know how to play the game. I played few different types of majong games most of them was hentai ones, but they had majong rules to help you understand and the dificulty level was more manageable. This game dont have majong rules explanation and difficulty is insane (the AI wins in 3-5 moves WTF is this BS)

author: {'steamid': '76561198045377291', 'num_games_owned': 1687, 'num_reviews': 80, 'playtime_forever': 820, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 758, 'last_played': 1696871782}
review:
Funny enough I do recommend this game if you like riichi-style mahjong and are already familiar with the game, but you need to know how to play going in, this is required! The game doesn't really provide a good tutorial on how to play. In my opinion no riichi-style mahjong game on Steam gives a good tutorial on how to play. You'd have a better chance learning how to play from Yakuza 0, which I recommend doing as it gives a good beginners look into the game. Not perfect though.

So the bottom line is...do you want a fast paced riichi-style mahjong game with "cute" anime girls squealing at you every 60 seconds? If yes, then get it on sale as the RRP is not worth it. If not, play Mahjong Nagomi. Mahjong Nagomi would be my favourite mahjong game on Steam if the game was a bit faster and the AI a bit smarter. Due to Mahjong Pretty Girls Battle fixing both of these issues for me, it will continue to be the primary riichi-style mahjong game for me. If you are wondering about the squealing anime girls being a problem, go into the options and mute them. Like I do...

If you are this far into my sh1tty review of this game simply because you'd like to learn how to play riichi-style mahjong. I don't know what to say...Yakuza 0 is pretty cheap (even cheaper when on sale) and the best Yakuza game ever made. So you'd could pick that up and have fun playing Yakuza 0 and then invest into the mahjong mini-game within. Watch the Akagi anime (it's what got me into riichi mahjong). The thing that taught me the most about riichi mahjong was a book called - Riichi Mahjong: The Ultimate Guide to the Japanese Game Taking the World by Storm - by the author Scott D. Miller. I couldn't follow any of the tutorials on YouTube as my attention span is abysmal, so I took my time reading that book while on lunch break at work. I'd recommend trying all three, why? Because it worked for me, I guess.

Also Tsubasa best girl, lol.

Also my favourite riichi mahjong game of all time is THE Mahjong on Switch. Seriously D3 Publisher...you need to bring that game to PC and localise it for western audiences. That games M1 mode is so good.

author: {'steamid': '76561198900216221', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 98, 'playtime_forever': 466, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 466, 'last_played': 1640548000}
review:
ANTES DE COMPRAR este juego es necesario seÃ±alar algunas ADVERTENCIAS:
1. El juego consiste en hacer 4 trios y una pareja (en tu mano), es el pÃ³ker de toda la vida pero con muchas fichas. Por lo que he podido observar, el 90% de las partidas se cierran por alguna que descarta la IA.
2. He leÃ­do por encima las normas del Mahjong y el problema que le veo es que hay distintos modos y lo que hace complicado este juego no es hacer mahjong, sino averiguar como se cierra porque, aunque tengas lo necesario en la mano para cerrar la ronda o la partida, no te deja, es como si hubiera que seguir determinado palo para hacerlo, sigue siendo un misterio para mÃ­. Del segundo puesto no suelo bajar.
3. A no ser que manejes mucho el tema del mahjong (me refiero a normas) puede llevarte horas este juego, yo solo he desbloqueado 3 personajes en 7 horas, pero no me cansa, me gusta.
4. No he visto por ningÃºn lado la opciÃ³n de jugar contra alguien, solamente IA.
5. No tiene contenido sexual el juego, asÃ­ que si buscas darte placer te equivocas de juego.

Punto negativo: cuando vas ganando de 8000-10000 puntos parece que ganas o empatas mÃ¡s partidas pero a veces no la cierra en la ronda 4, o tienes que perder la ronda o tienes que hacer mahjong.
CONCLUSIÃ“N:
El juego es guaay si te gustan los retos y el mahjong, enserio que es un reto constante.

author: {'steamid': '76561198035985069', 'num_games_owned': 845, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 415, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 415, 'last_played': 1553384080}
review:
(This is an identical review to Mahjong Pretty Girls Battle: Schoolgirl Edition as the games are functionally identical with different characters)

This is a functional Riichi Mahjong game that has some cute anime girls as your own and the AI's characters. 

It DOES function properly and follows the rules and even has customizable options for certain hands. It however does NOTHING to teach you how to play the game. So if you don't know how to play you're just going to be very very lost. The AI speeds is stupidly fast to the point you can't even comprehend what they're doing. Doing your own actions takes an excessive amount of clicks. The translation is...questionable at best so you're not going to learn many proper terms for even English audiences of Riichi Mahjong and if you already know them...well then you're just going to be confused. 

Does the game work? Yes it does. Is it a good way to play? Very likely not because you can't learn with this and if you know how to play...you're already playing somewhere better. Only buy this if you really just want mahjong with cute anime girls (And even that can be found elsewhere).

[h1]+[/h1]
*Cute anime girls as the characters.
*It functions to the rules of Riichi Mahjong

[h1]---[/h1]
*You will not learn how to play
*The pacing is absurd and honestly broken
*Unlocking anything takes forever
*You only play against AI (That's honestly either bad or cheaty it feels at times)
*The translation is just....wow

author: {'steamid': '76561197982893207', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 156, 'playtime_forever': 954, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 954, 'last_played': 1426445881}
review:
It's at least real Mahjong in contrast to those tile matching search thingies. 

But it's not Mahjong Soul. I will now go play Mahjong Soul, as it is simply way better (and free).

This did allow me to play riichi mahjong on steam at the time it came out, so it was positive.

author: {'steamid': '76561198114641915', 'num_games_owned': 3, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 201, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 201, 'last_played': 1608706860}

author: {'steamid': '76561198043135631', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2248, 'playtime_forever': 282, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 282, 'last_played': 1501193814}
review:
Ricchi Mahjong can be extremely hard to learn.
If you haven't played Ricchi before: Avoid this.
This game really is for the experienced players.
Not even a proper tutorial, so keep tis in mind.
I know about Ricchi from the Yakuza franchise.
That's where I learned how to play these cards.
And it's honestly a really good 1v3 card game.
It reminds me of Poker, but it's a lot different.
Well, anyways: The AI of this game is terrible.
Not even the nice visuals can fix the AI issue.
But it's still quite enjoyable to actually play it.
This waifu franchise actually has two games.
And the gameplay in them really is identical.
The only difference is the waifus inside of it.
Both games have the same AI issues as well.
I'm gonna give them both a positive review.
Mostly because I do enjoy Ricchi Mahjong.

author: {'steamid': '76561198008053657', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 251, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 192, 'last_played': 1608360354}
review:
I caught the mahjong bug pretty recently and am trying a bunch of ways to play this. This is a bad way. It's got weird balance shit going on which fine if you want that conceit, but not good if you are trying to learn mahjong. On top of that it is just a very poorly put together thing. I turned the volume all the way down in the settings and it hard crashed. It feels very cheap, it does not use Riichi mahjong terms that literally every other thing I've tried uses. And it has extremely unrealistic unlock conditions for the other characters, you better be ready to grind this not so great Mahjong game. 

Its hard to really recommend many games if you just want to play Mahjong against a computer. The Yakuza series has some pretty good versions of it, Kiwami 2 and up probably specifically better than like Zero. There's also Mahjong Soul which is basically this but as a gacha game and much higher quality while being free to play, though that game is very limited options for playing against AI.  This is not it though.

author: {'steamid': '76561198118396010', 'num_games_owned': 163, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 360, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 197, 'last_played': 1656363607}
review:
I mean it's just a kinda bad Riichi-Mahjong engine. Works well enough if you know the rules but if not, good luck. There are plenty of engines out there that are probably better and allow for online multiplayer, which this one does not. I'm only okay with this because it's basically free during the sale. 

If you were looking for some cute girls, good luck or better yet, don't bother. Unlocking more besides the starting 4 takes a huge amount of grind. I've played 3 hours and unlocked a single new character. You have to win a certain amount of games with one character to unlock the next in that row. The first new characters take 3 wins. Then 5, 7 and 10. There are also special unlocks like an overall of 10 & 100 games played, a certain amount of games won, won with 20 different kinds of hands etc. Not worth the grind.

Tl;dr: buy this if it's on sale for like 1-2 bucks and you don't already have an atleast decent engine to play Riichi-Mahjong, but not if you don't understand the rules. I know those last 2 points are kinda paradoxical.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044499425', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 488, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 337, 'last_played': 1682915824}
review:
I hate this game because its the only Real Mahjong game, the one with four players on steam which is great. But I hate that its not multi player so I can play against real people and I hate that the only way to play mahjong is to play a game called "Mahjong Pretty Girls Battle" I don't mind anime biddies but I would rather this game be based around something with a more fitting theme. I would kill for a Akagi Mod or something.

Update: SO I found out you can play this kinda Mahjong in Yakuza 0 and it even has a multiplayer mode so there's that

author: {'steamid': '76561198047344005', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 2325, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2325, 'last_played': 1551163848}
review:
Easy to play many modes and options.

The best real Mahjong game Steam has to offer to date but I am still looking for a true Hong Kong rule based version without girls would be fine, that is just as friendly and easy as this one is.  If there is actually any nudity its probably at least a hundred hours into the game play. What's with the Bat wings, not exactly a Furry is it? I get nervous sick feeling even thinking that any of these girls (even in a virtual animated world) might be under 18 years old. I recommend they make the girls look older, please.

author: {'steamid': '76561198105228037', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 99, 'playtime_forever': 33, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 33, 'last_played': 1546802014}
review:
The reach mahjong animation takes at least 5-10 seconds because they have to spin it.  Then of course the girls take a while to unlock, no character/outfit customization nor subtitles for the voice acting, which again, makes the game slow if I do not know what they are saying.  As others said, no tutorial so I can't recommend it unless it's on sale, and there isn't any competition if you need riichi/real mahjong (not solitaire) for steam.

I could easily recommend if they fixed this laziness, made easier unlocks (given no story mode, I shouldn't have to win 3 matches as each of the starting 4 characters to unlock only 1 character; concealed/discard kong with ron/tsumo would've been sufficient), added subtitles, and had a store with points from your wins to buy outfits (no DLC of course), rather than pay extra for the school girls edition, which is a cash grab.  

If you don't have language barrier problems, there's the gundam mahjong on the ds as well as girl mahjong games on gba (mobile is a bit hard to find actual characters to play as and the mobile games are titled in Japanese so it's hard for me to specifically name them.

author: {'steamid': '76561198062296741', 'num_games_owned': 870, 'num_reviews': 127, 'playtime_forever': 14, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 14, 'last_played': 1532117709}
review:
Like a lot of other people I am completely new to this form of Mahjong and therefor was completely unable to play the game since it doesn't offer any kind of tutorial or training. 
The moment you start the game, you are thrown into your first round of Mahjong and basically play random tiles in hopes something good happens. However, it's not only the tutorial that is missing, even if you try to look through the 'Help' option or the 'Rules' option you aren't offered any kind of instructions on how to play. 
Players in the community themselves took it onto them to publish guides on how to actually play the game.

However, me being unable to play simply because I don't know the rules, doesn't justify me giving a bad review of a game since it can be a good experience for others who actually do know how to play. I did read through some of the other reviews though and it seems that even players with experience struggle with some aspects of the game and therefor I stick with the bad review since I myself can't recommend it (at least for newbies) and experienced players also seem too struggle with a recommendation. 

Do not recommend, unless you are already feeling at home with the rules of Mahjong.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970433469', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 57, 'playtime_forever': 168, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 73, 'last_played': 1528725977}

author: {'steamid': '76561198009474997', 'num_games_owned': 2217, 'num_reviews': 1072, 'playtime_forever': 234, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 234, 'last_played': 1520005821}
review:
This game is not very user friendly and unless you are experienced with Japanese Mahjong you will have an incredible difficult time playing and enjoying this game.


A few tings to note:

It seems that with this one the Translations has been done better than with some of the rest making for an Localized English version.  Different voice actors for different characters, each character has their own unique play styles which adds variety to the mix. 


No Multiplayer
No Tutorials or any kind of help.
The games interface is not very smooth or appealing it plays and feels very clunky.

Still slightly overpriced in my opinion.

author: {'steamid': '76561198095920283', 'num_games_owned': 1186, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 131, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 131, 'last_played': 1523078130}
review:
the game gives no direction on how to play nor does it offer some kind of tutorial for beginners.
The girls are just one picture while the rounds could last a long time for no real reason but i dont really understand 
the game either.
it wasnt a fun experience trying to learn to play the game just to unlock some characters. Also to unlock these
characters invloves a grinding sesion that is no way any fun to do when the girls just have one custome nor does it 
have any other incentives other than the achievments. 
Overrall it was a chore to play this game and it just does not justify the price tag.
Also the game giltches out whenever i tired to change the window size.
2/10 nope

author: {'steamid': '76561198413987657', 'num_games_owned': 3035, 'num_reviews': 129, 'playtime_forever': 298, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 298, 'last_played': 1519952369}
review:
So, let me start of by saying that I love Mahjong. As in, actual Mahjong, not the tile matching version that most people I ask think IS Mahjong. It's a game my family has been playing many times over, to the point that it's become kind of a staple game that we even bring on holiday trips. However, we obviously don't play it the 'proper' way. We had a small, older book explaining various rules etc, but we still played relatively casual. No 30k points combos for us, haha.

Why am I including this in my review? We'll, I've been itching for some time to play the real game, to learn the combos, the tricks, the various rules, basically to step my game up and deepen my knowledge about this family favourite. More often than not, when I was looking for a computer version, I ended up with the solitaire version instead. So, finding the actual game was like a breath of fresh air. I didn't get it for the pretty girls specifically but I figured they wouldn't hurt the fun either.

Thing is, there aren't really any instructions. I knew from the family session what a Pung or Kong were etc, but I had no idea why certain other things were happening, what melding was, any of that. I still had fun playing but I was still a casual playing against AIs who knew what they were doing.

It was helpful that the game auto-alerts you to when a discarded tile is usable for you, since it'll get harder to spot the more crowded the board gets. But there was no guidance otherwise. Each of the girls even has different AI operatives with different strengths and preferences that I wouldn't even know how to counter because I had no idea what they were to begin with. So unless you know your Mahjong, you're probably better off picking a different game that has some explanations. I'd wanna give a neutral thumb since I still had fun playing despite not knowing what to do in detail, but since it can be only one or the other... I suppose if it was a little cheaper I'd recommend, but at this price I can't whole-heartedly do so. Maybe the price is proportionate to cup size inside... I'll probably never find out XD

All of these girls are characters from various Visual Novels, so if there's one you've taken a liking to you're in luck since she'll be in at least one other game (and potentially in another game like this one). Although I can't guarantee that you'll like what you'll find... or maybe you will. Look them up at your own risk if you're so inclined.

author: {'steamid': '76561198135438892', 'num_games_owned': 4732, 'num_reviews': 5177, 'playtime_forever': 295, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 272, 'last_played': 1520367858}
review: Very nice game

author: {'steamid': '76561198142428668', 'num_games_owned': 2729, 'num_reviews': 64, 'playtime_forever': 119, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 119, 'last_played': 1519605980}
review:
Eh... Mahjong Pretty Girls Battle is a hard one to review. Number one reason, I have no clue on how to play Mahjong and the game did not provide a helpful help guide. Now if you are someone who knows the game, loves pretty anime girls, you'll more likely enjoy the game. For someone like me who has no clue, yeah.. not so much. I bought the game in a bundle. I don't regret the purchase however would not buy the game on it's own. Again, if I knew Mahjong, might be a different story. 

As of right now, I can't recommend the game for beginners looking to learn Mahjong. If you are experience, have at it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198330549421', 'num_games_owned': 240, 'num_reviews': 42, 'playtime_forever': 1540, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1303, 'last_played': 1521724650}
review:
It's impossible to unlock all of characters. No way to beat AI which always can do "Rii-chi" every round and win the game every time. No idea why their tiles always better than player.

How am I supposed to win cheating AIs? It's not fun if playing in spite of the fact knowing the player never have a chance to win over AIs. It's impossible to finish 1st until unlock every character over such cheating AIs. Who can do that?

I will recommend this game if there is easy mode or balance AIs not too hard to beat if this is really casual game.

5/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198101974519', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 64, 'playtime_forever': 278, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 278, 'last_played': 1506648814}
review:
After giving poor ratings this morning to a couple of other games in the "Pretty Girls" series (Mahjong Solitaire and Poker Battle), I was very pleasantly surprised by this one. Japanese (Riichi) mahjong is very different from the solitaire tile game, and it's even harder to find a good digital version. This one is actually decent, with a few caveats. First, don't attempt this complex game if you don't know the rules, because you won't learn them here. There is no tutorial, and the only available help is in a few sentences of poorly translated text. In the How to Play section, for example, you'll read this: "It lifts when hand tile is done in the click once. When the same tile is done in the click again, it throws it away to the place." And in the actual Rules section (which really just outlines the options available in this version), you'll find this example: "East round, leader is changed When leader is no ready hand." 

If you're already familiar with Riichi mahjong, then you'll find the action here to be pretty fast, and the controls are intuitive. All special moves (such as chi, pon, and kan) and the dora are completely automated. There are a couple of features I'd like to see implemented. For example, you cannot arrange the tiles in your hand (that's also automated), and there is no confirmation for normal moves. More than once I've accidentally got rid of the wrong tile by clicking too fast, but these are really minor complaints. A bigger complaint is that the game itself is not configurable. You can't, for example, alter the number of hands in each round, so you're stuck with the standard 4-hand-2-round game, which will take you a while. (Saving mid-game doesn't seem to be an option, either. EDIT: The game supposedly autosaves on exit, but it hasn't worked for me.) Sounds and music are well done, and there are even video resolutions available, which is a rarity in this series. Unfortunately, it lacks multiplayer, but you can find that on several browser-based versions if that's your thing. Because of the solo-only play and lack of game configuration options, the current price point of US $15 is about $5 too high, but it's frequently on sale and has been bundled twice already. Wait for a sale, and then pick it up. Recommended.

For those of you who would like to learn how to play this ancient and addictive game, I recommend this excellent video by HanaYoriUta: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hlnC2rgIPrc 
It's 3.5 hours long, but you'll be able to play fairly well after watching the first hour.

author: {'steamid': '76561198040594264', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 5902, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2703, 'last_played': 1646634682}
review:
Not for beginners. If you're looking for something that'll hold your hand as you learn how to play mahjong, this isn't it.
If you know how to play however, it's good enough if you just want to play mahjong and you don't have an internet connection.
The AI have different play style between the characters (they provide decent challenge, btw) and you can customize the rules to your liking.
Yes, the interface could use some polishing and  yes, yaku names could use some better implementation. 
Do I care? No, not really, honestly. (Maybe bexause I know exactly what I'm paying for here.)

author: {'steamid': '76561198027267313', 'num_games_owned': 1838, 'num_reviews': 4460, 'playtime_forever': 262, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 262, 'last_played': 1505066458}
review:
Tags: Boards & Cards - Mahjong
Additional Tags: Delete Local Content & Remove from Library

TLDR: Thin experience 

This uses a combat version of mahjong where you can repick tiles and build a board, presumably with something to do with picture matching. Not sure if you match yourself or opponents and I am not too interested to find out. This suffers from the same lack of polish, lack of fan service and overall value that you can find in the Poker version of the game which I found more intuitive and engaging than this and that game got removed for declutter as well.

review:
So... This game is interesting. However, I can only recommend it to those who know what the heck they are doing. Unlike some of their other games, the instructions are... not clear. So while I was getting trios and other matches to other players' tiles... I still was losing badly... all the time.

So... cannot recommend this for the casual player...

author: {'steamid': '76561198059853407', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 3883, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3634, 'last_played': 1699687687}
review:
It's a great mahjong game if you want a straight and authentic game of mahjong. The cute girls are there for show, the main focus of this game is the mahjong game itself.

If you are completely new to mahjong and are looking to learn (like myself), then it's much better to go online and look for a tutorial and a list of yaku rather than poking around and hope you pick it up as you go along. First of all, the computer is quite good and you probably wont figure out how to properly win a hand because the computer will always win before you can learn anything. Secondly, the names of the yaku in English are strange or badly translated. You wont know what yaku you have until the end of the match and they have the strangest names, making it hard to search up online to see how or what the combination was.

All in all, it's a great game if you already know how to play, or if you are learning, but already know the basic rules. If you know some basic Japanese, then it's much better to switch the language to Japanese so you can get the names of the yaku at the end and look them up for reference.

author: {'steamid': '76561198033624455', 'num_games_owned': 782, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 4884, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2807, 'last_played': 1702423677}
review:
The name might seem a little off-putting for some, but if you want to delve into Japanese-style mahjong then this is pretty much the only option on Steam right now. The "Schoolgirl edition" is the same game just with a different skin. 

GAMEPLAY

In terms of Riichi rules, the options menu allows you to configure the ruleset to your preference (length of game, red 5's, particular Yaku's etc). 

The AI of each character is set to prefer a particular playstyle, to take extra risks in attack or be safer in defense, to favour melds or triplets etc. 

Game progression is measured through unlocking characters, so you basically play each character to win a set number of times and unlock the next character. All the while the detailed stats page will keep track of all your results so that say after 50 or so games you will be able to analyse your playstyle.  

There is also a list of in-game achievements but these are not rendered in Steam. 


SOUND AND LOOKS

There are two language options, Japanese or English. The English translation is not very well rendered and does not seem to have been done by a native speaker. You should be able to figure it out though. 

The 23 playable characters consist of happy picture & sound clip, and a sad one. That's it - you might find one or two annoying after a bit but if you keep your opponents randomised then you won't notice as much. There's nothing inappropriate for say ages 15 & over - some of the characters have revealing clothes or a large busom and that's that. 

The music is OK but very repetitive. A couple of extra tracks could have made this much better.

The playfield is excellently rendered. You have a couple of options for viewpoints and table colour, and the display style is clear and intuitive. The tiles are neatly differentiated. 


CONCLUSION

Mahjong Pretty Girls Battle is, at heart, a solid one-player Riichi Mahjong game which you can trust to bring your skills up to scratch, Beyond that, there's no multiplayer, so you will need to use this to "graduate" towards a web-based title.

author: {'steamid': '76561198047775291', 'num_games_owned': 299, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 36, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'last_played': 1482864881}
review:
I know this is the only actual riichi mahjong game on steam available (at least here) but honestly: there are better alternatives to this for free on PC, just not on Steam. The girls aren't even that pretty, the graphics are kinda poor, music is kinda meh, and I didn't see any option to keep original romanized names of everything (hands, pon/kan/chi etc.) which isn't much pain, but could be there...

And it has no netplay. You can just go play Tenhou, Sega NET Mahjong MJ or one of many other free options. 

If you don't know how to play mahjong, this won't teach you anyway, so check out the free ones.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993596060', 'num_games_owned': 3228, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 13693, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2411, 'last_played': 1559190273}
review:
This is the best (and only) non solitaire mahjong game on steam. That said its actually pretty good. The major caveat being that it teaches you nothing about how to play. (Also I could do without the "pretty girls" schtick tbh, its mildly embarassing but is pretty much just title screen fan service anyway).
I'm pretty sure I still have no idea how to play but I've managed to start winning fairly consistently (or at least not losing massively). I wish it had a more clear layout of what the possible winning hands are as I often seem to have a winning hand but get stuck in a loop of sacred discard. I think it has something to do with not having completed a yaku.
The game would greatly benefit from just a little static screen that shows the yaku and (and other hands?) like koi koi has. Obviously I can google that but I've got no real insight as to exactly which of the 4096 variants I'm actually playing here.

Anyway, if you want to suffer through learning how to play, already know how to play and want to play against AI, or just like reloading the title screen to look at anime girls, it's totally worth a sale buy.

author: {'steamid': '76561197972297308', 'num_games_owned': 4497, 'num_reviews': 203, 'playtime_forever': 158, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 158, 'last_played': 1474176686}
review:
I decided to try this game out after finishing Pretty Girls Mahjong Solitaire, and let me just say this - the two games are nothing alike.

With the solitaire version I could just pick it up and start playing right away without a need for any tutorial or explanation. With this version I was thrown right into a match having no clue what to do next.

I did read a tutorial/guide online while playing the game, and within two hours I somehow managed to win a 4-round match with around 60 000 points (which I assume is good, as the AI usually didn't get that many points when they beat me), but I'm not really sure exactly [i]how[/i] I won.

If you, like me, don't know how to play Mahjong I can't really recommend this game. If you already know the rules then I guess you might enjoy this game, however the art and sound are very mediocre.

If you [i]do[/i] decide to get this game you might as well just wait for a 90% discount, as those seem to come around quite often.

Review: [url=http://steamcommunity.com/id/imthetoad/recommended/393980/]Pretty Girls Mahjong Solitaire[/url]
Review: [url=http://steamcommunity.com/id/imthetoad/recommended/540610]Delicious! Pretty Girls Mahjong Solitaire[/url]

author: {'steamid': '76561198064153655', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 281, 'playtime_forever': 1683, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1175, 'last_played': 1474245069}
review:
+) Mahjong became familiar game for me.
 (I still don't understand what is what most of the times but I ronned and chumoed time to time hahahaha and secure my victory in the end.)
+) Characters were beautiful.
+) Tile was clean and you can pick its color and also the color of the table.
+) You can change the game rules and there are quite a fun options there.
+) Character unlocking system was motivational.

-) BGM is bad. There's only one I think. I muted it and played Akagi's bgm hahahahaha.
-) Scroll in the option menu is weird.

author: {'steamid': '76561198055530890', 'num_games_owned': 233, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 1315, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 709, 'last_played': 1653318383}
review:
Honestly, I could go either way with this game. Here's the short version: If you know how to play Riichi Mahjong already, and want a classic 4-player Mahjong game to play on Steam by yourself, go ahead and buy this.

Here's the long version. This game has no tutorial or help system at all, so unless you have a deep understanding of how Japanese Mahjong works, you will be pretty lost at this game. It also has no multiplayer system of any kind - you can only play with CPU players. I personally have no problem with that, but I know a few people who do, so I'm mentioning that.

There's really not a whole lot to this game actually. You can change the rules to some degree, but it has no special features, so honestly, I find the game a little bit overpriced. But given how there are no other games on Steam like this (at the time this review was written), I'm still happy that this at least exists. You can either love it or hate it. Me, personally? I'd play it, but it's not real special. It does what it says on the box, but that's about it.

And by the way, if you know of any other games like this on Steam (excluding Tabletop Simulator), please comment on this review to tell me about it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198097309462', 'num_games_owned': 551, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 799, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 276, 'last_played': 1501484562}
review:
Sad the best PC mahjong game has balloon tit women with super high pitch voices. 

It's certainly not the best riichi mahjong game out there, but very acceptable. The play field is nice, the selecting and tossing of tiles is done with a mouse, it does highlight Tsumo/Ron/Chi/Pon/Kan opporunities, it even does a nice job of highlighting dora tiles, and matches can be set to a comfortable single wind amount of rounds. Also, while pretty exploitive, collecting all the girls does give you incentive to keep playing, and they all do have their own little quirks (some annoying, some cute). 

I dislike many of the names used for yaku and scoring. I'm so used to Japanese names that it's hard calling things a "slam" and a "run". While these are very English, much of the in-game titles are their Chinese counterparts(chow, pung, etc). I feel like the game should have selected one language (bias towards Japanese) and stuck with it. 

This AI seems fair enough. I feel like I don't get dealt as good a hand as other mahjong game software (rarely get two honors), but I do tend to win matches enough to feel good about it. This is a nice relief from the old arcade mahjong games which absolutely cheat and rob you. If anything, I'd maybe like to see an enhanced mode of sorts which allow items and/or abilities to increase luck, turn up all doras, allow you to see an opponent's hand, etc. Most console mahjong games have had these items and abilities thrown into them to make the game more enjoyable and interesting, shame to have it gone here. 

Also, if you're looking to learn mahjong, it's not happening here. I recommend learning how to play elsewhere, though, as mahjong is a fun game in general.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042246485', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 6748, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4673, 'last_played': 1537568092}
review:
This is the best (and only) non solitaire mahjong game on steam. That said its actually pretty good. The major caveat being that it teaches you nothing about how to play. (Also I could do without the "pretty girls" schtick tbh, its mildly embarassing but is pretty much just title screen fan service anyway).
I'm pretty sure I still have no idea how to play but I've managed to start winning fairly consistently (or at least not losing massively). I wish it had a more clear layout of what the possible winning hands are as I often seem to have a winning hand but get stuck in a loop of sacred discard. I think it has something to do with not having completed a yaku.
The game would greatly benefit from just a little static screen that shows the yaku and (and other hands?) like koi koi has. Obviously I can google that but I've got no real insight as to exactly which of the 4096 variants I'm actually playing here.

Anyway, if you want to suffer through learning how to play, already know how to play and want to play against AI, or just like reloading the title screen to look at anime girls, it's totally worth a sale buy.

author: {'steamid': '76561198012778917', 'num_games_owned': 2877, 'num_reviews': 165, 'playtime_forever': 157, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 157, 'last_played': 1461737341}
review:
I guess the major point of the game is the amount of girls and their looks. But, even though that, this game actually plays surprisingly well.

You will need to know what to do, you need to know how to play Mahjong, to play this, but it actually does a pretty good job of monitoring the outcomes. It also helps you a lot, indicating when you can win and also pausing the game when a tile is played, something that does not occur in a normal game. So, the game actually makes it pretty easy for you.
Yet, the ai seems pretty strong sometimes, they can make some pretty good plays, finishing the game quick. You actually have to be careful.

From this game and the "school edition" there is no difference at all. You shouldn't buy both. Well, I don't actually recommend you to buy any, since I think that this game lacks a lot of content for its price. But, if you must play a good game of mahjong (only with AI), you may consider this...

Yes, this is the same review, since the game is the same.

author: {'steamid': '76561198072490385', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 566, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 297, 'last_played': 1607867416}
review:
+ >This is true Riichi Mahjong.
+ >On English.
+ >Nice gamedesign.
(+ >[i]Pretty anime-girls with large (and also not very) you-know-what...[/i])

---[b]MINUS!!![/b] >[b]English named Yaku![/b] [u]"Call"[/u]? [u]"All simple"[/u]?? [u]"Pung/Chew/Kang"[/u]??? [b]Realy???[/b]
Where is so familiar [u]"Taniao-pinfu-dora-dora"[/u]???
- >High price. 10$ for Mahjong? Realy? IMHO ~5$ is nice price for Mahjong game.
- >It would be possible also add the online mode. 
We have only [i]tenhou.net[/i] or [i]ron2.jp[/i] which are fully in Japanese...

So what to do if PLUSES and MINUSES are equal?
If you like Riichi Mahjong and [b]know the rules![/b] you should buy it (but only on sale^^)
Otherwise skip it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198005120813', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 347, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 321, 'last_played': 1637447298}
review:
This is perhaps the most poorly designed games I have ever played.

And no, it's not the mahjong that is poorly designed. Mahjong is an unimpeachable of spectacular fun.

It's the literal design choices in the user interface and the pacing of the AI.

Every single fucking transition in the game whenever a CPU 'pong's or 'chi's literally breaks the game's flow.
Every single screen that gets in the way between each round.
The inability to check the table after a match ends.
The need to drag your mouse around in order to see the other player's melds.
The shoddly 12fps animation in the title screen.
No animation for tile's being placed down. They just appear out of nowhere and it's distracting.
Annoying music.
Unresponsive interface.
The scrollbar in the settings screen for screen size does not correspond to how you drag the scroll bar, but rather the inner window.
Whenever you resize the window, the window literally freezes for a good 5 seconds. How hard is it to render mahjong tiles.

And not even 'pretty girls' can save this game. The characters literally have no character. While yes, they do have voice acting, but for what reason?
They aren't animated and furthermore, they have absolutely no backstory.
Honestly I would much rather play faceless bots.
I won't have to deal with the high pitched squeals, a transition in whenever a pon or chi happens, and comically oversized proportions (I'm looking at you Rui and Ayumi).
When you unlock characters, there's honestly no sense of accomplishment.

Couldn't even deliver a mahjong experience, let alone a character driven game.
If you understood Japanese I would direct you to the free ones that are available.

author: {'steamid': '76561197991556578', 'num_games_owned': 436, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 948, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 744, 'last_played': 1467922758}
review: Mahjong Riichi + Waifus = Sugoku Kimochi <3

author: {'steamid': '76561197971532357', 'num_games_owned': 2752, 'num_reviews': 413, 'playtime_forever': 191, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 191, 'last_played': 1457258311}
review:
I love mahjong since I was a kid. However, I wasn't aware that two versions existed: the solitaire one, which is the version I love, and a sort of poker one, which I don't understand anything despite trying to decypher the rules in the help of the game.

True, I could have searched elsewhere but for me, the version presented here isn't interesting me. My brain isn't really strategy-oriented, which is why you don't ask me to play poker or other cards games if you're more interested by winning than to pass a good moment.

Mahjong Pretty Girls Battle could have been a good game for me if the rules were clear (they're not well translated) and if there was a real tutorial included. However, I ended up to play by instinct, which reserved sometimes a good suprise but almost all the time, I got defeated by the AI.

I suppose that for anyone used to this version of mahjong, the game is very enjoyable, though your only real visual is a board with the tiles. However, the characters are girls drawed for fanservice: some have big breasts (not really realistic), others are normal.

Besides, the soundtrack isn't remarkable but after a while, you'll get used to girls screaming because they have a winning move and you don't understand how they arrived to that.

My three hours ingame reflect mainly idling for cards, but I've giving up pretty quickly to try to understand the rules. I'm pretty happy with my solitaire version, which isn't requiring to plan carefully your next move (well, yeah, you have sometimes to plan carefully your move but you don't have adversaries in front of you, ready to take advantage of your discarded tile).

I should probably thumb down the game, however, I will not: the fact that I didn't really enjoy came from my lack of willingness to learn more about this version of Majhong. In that case, I recommend the game only for those that are understanding the rules of it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198011535220', 'num_games_owned': 423, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 190, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 88, 'last_played': 1560896217}
review: I've played many riichi mahjong games before. There are free games that are way better then this. Really, don't bother your time on this game. It does allow for different rule sets, but the game itself is pretty choppy. You can set the AI speed to almost instant, but everytime someone makes a meld or win, it goes into some kind of very slow and lame looking girl on girl animation. I'm glad mahjong is coming to steam, but only get this game if it's below 5 USD or Euro. It's not worth more.

I want a refund!

author: {'steamid': '76561197989985442', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 1159, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1011, 'last_played': 1454176378}
review:
Buy it because of the name. 
Install it because of the cards. 
Start playing it because you heard its not beginner friendly. 
Keep playing because its a lot of fun! 
 
When I first started playing this game I had no idea how to play mahjong but I just couldn't let a bunch of girls beat me and walk away. So I looked up some guides that I didn't understand and with a lot of loosing and struggling I finally started to understand the game a bit. By now I think I have quite a fair chance at winning and have a lot of fun playing the game. 
 
If you are new to Japanese mahjong I would recommend that you look up a guide on YouTube or google and give the game a try its really fun!

author: {'steamid': '76561198105540729', 'num_games_owned': 334, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 5, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5, 'last_played': 1450823230}
review:
Don't get me wrong - this game probably great - tha is if you know how to play this ype of Mahjong.

I didn't notice at all it wasn't Solitare Mahjong that most of us are used to because of MS Window's games and the app shops of our phones. I refuned the games (I got the bundle) because even though I was ready to try to learn this type of Mahjong, there wasn't any "How to play".

All in all I can't in any way recommend this to others like me that can't play this type of Mahjong, for the others, I thing it's worth trying.

author: {'steamid': '76561198017130613', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1297, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1151, 'last_played': 1559066566}
review:
An okay single player riichi mahjong game. Would be better if you could customize the rules a bit more. Most mahjong games let you toggle every rule imaginable, but this game has somewhat limited options.
Each AI supposedly has its own playstyle, but they all seem exactly the same to me.
You can actually break the rules and pay a chombo penalty in some areas, so be careful. Most mahjong games won't even let you take illegal actions. A good point for this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198018466482', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 155, 'playtime_forever': 24, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 24, 'last_played': 1448471515}
review: More than 20 years have passed and still there's no Mahjong game that can beat Hong Kong Mahjong Pro. Oh well.

author: {'steamid': '76561198089299679', 'num_games_owned': 7216, 'num_reviews': 392, 'playtime_forever': 263, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 263, 'last_played': 1508479184}
review:
Well for a Game that sales animation girls's skin as feature this one is very poorly done. 
You don't get any fan service at all.. and you don't get any Plots like most Japnese ecchi animation game...

You have to win 200 games to unlock all the girls even but there are not much surprise when they are unlocked...

All the girls have different MahJang status but I couldn't find any AI behaviour diference between each one.

Japnese mahjong is also quite different then the GongDong and Shanghai MahJong that i am use to.

4.0/10.. not recommend for anyone.. Except maybe japnese MahJong lover.

author: {'steamid': '76561197997115431', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 648, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 143, 'last_played': 1706981441}
review:
This is really a great mahjong game, and I think I will spend many hours playing this game.

So, why not recomment it ?

Because you HAVE TO know how to play mahjong BEFORE playing the game. There is no tutorial, no rules explanation, and lots of annoucements are in japanese (or other asian language).

You have to know how to play mahjong to be able to play to this game. But if you do, I think it's a really good (single player) game to do so.

PS : this is the real game of mahjong, not the puzzle-like game you could find in windows...

author: {'steamid': '76561198067663151', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 36, 'playtime_forever': 67, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 49, 'last_played': 1446417407}
review:
Buy it if it's 90% off / $1.49 or something, otherwise, skip it. If you're new to Japanese mahjong, this game is not for you. Besides the shoddy English translation (I just kept the language as Japanese since it was irritating to see Chow and Call and other garbage rather than just the Japanese words w/ explanations. I just bought it for the crappy mahjong, and even then it isn't even that great. If you're familiar with JP mahjong, just stick to tenhou, this is a shoddy imitation that feels like it should have come out 10-15 years ago. There's no multiplayer, the music is terrible, and sometimes the draws seem really really bogus. 

I don't really regret buying it for 2 bucks though, since it's mildly entertaining. It's like I'm really playing Saki !

author: {'steamid': '76561198106910808', 'num_games_owned': 565, 'num_reviews': 55, 'playtime_forever': 589, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 44, 'last_played': 1459836773}

author: {'steamid': '76561198049213193', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 140, 'playtime_forever': 238, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 200, 'last_played': 1447563189}
review:
I'll say yes due to the price but if you've got no clue how to play Mahjong, this will not teach you.  I've been stumbling my way through using a guide to Mahjong in general but since I'm not sure why certain things are happening or how to adjust the rules to something that might be easier to play some games I end up more frustrated than anything else.

This game desperately needs a tutorial mode.  And I will admit I should have read the reviews before purchasing because of that fact.

The music is alright.  I've only unlocked one of the girls so no big info on that.  So far I don't find the voices hard to listen to.

I do like that it's very easy to play through a full game without a lot of time being consumed so it's a fast play if nothing else.

The tiles are very easy to read and the ability to 'view mode' simply by holding down the cursor on the table and moving the mouse helps see what has already been disguarded.

Not a game for beginners unless you're willing to do a lot of trial and error.

author: {'steamid': '76561198080599829', 'num_games_owned': 529, 'num_reviews': 108, 'playtime_forever': 1818, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 719, 'last_played': 1671792822}
review:
I wouldn't say it's is great, but it is good enough to be a time killer. what would make it a lot greater is if it has Achievements and Online Gameplay. When I bought it, I didn't know how to play, so I looked up a few tutorials and it took me no longer than a day or three to get used to the game. If you DON'T know how to play, a person on YouTube named HanaYoriUta can help you out on the basics. Keep in mind this game will not teach you at all and the tutorials on the game itself are messy (at least to me)
This game is highly reccomended over the School Girls Edition if you don't know how to read the tiles because they're in Japanese. In this game, they're translated.
It's not as hard as I thought it would be when I first learned, so with a little motivation, anyone can get used to this game in less than a week.

author: {'steamid': '76561198222003100', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 77, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 77, 'last_played': 1446725590}
review:
Se voce quiser comprar muito mesmo esse jogo, pague apenas quando tiver 3 dolares... pra nao se arrepender(muito) depois

Ok! Regras Japonesa e etc etc etc.... Eu semprei joguei O mahjong japones e sempre gostei de toda sua complexidade em relacao aos outros. Mas mesmo pra alguem que goste de MOE/ANIME/BOOBS ainda assim eu nao recomendo que voce ompre esse jogo. Pra comecar existem somente 4 personagens de inicio, pra habilitar o resto voce tem que vencer inumeras vezes em primeiro lugar, o que nao seria muito facil SE EXISTISSE um modo story. De fato fica bem chato logo nas primeiras horas, dai pra descobrir que tem que jogar muito pra habilitar as outras personagens. Nao tem modo torneio, nao tem absolutamente nada. Apenas o jogo e mais as vozes.
Segunda coisa eh que se houvesse pelo menos o modo multiplayer, isso salvaria a pele do jogo. O player nao sente motivado pra jogar porque existem jogos em flash online gratuitos pra jogar online, sem contar sites que contem avatar e graficos bem modernos. 

As partes boas sao as vozes e as imagens das personagens...

author: {'steamid': '76561197995392614', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 398, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 242, 'last_played': 1484173151}
review:
VERY highly recommended for this price ($1.49/2.49 bundle) if you ALREADY can play basic level riichi mahjong. It is a port of the best android riichi mahjong game (trust me I have played every android mahjong game), "Nagomi Mahjong," but it has kawaii girl-chans added in. Fair AI, there are about 20 characters with different AI but you must unlock the characters. Progression is good, it is not a grindfest for unlocks like other Japanese games (eg. get 1st 3 or 5 times with character). 

In the bundle the two games are exactly the same except for the characters, however the schoolgirls characters are not as good. Still worth getting the bundle.

Game can go up to 1440p but is locked at 20fps. Does not made a difference because the game has no fluid motions. Game is singleplayer-only. Has very little fanservice. Family friendly tbh.


daburu yakuman out of 5

author: {'steamid': '76561198025575091', 'num_games_owned': 1042, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 4244, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 995, 'last_played': 1701511560}
review:
Disclaimer: I bought this when it was 90% off (for about $1.50)

The simplified translation might turn some people off, but it doesn't really bother me. Putting "Call" instead of "Riichi" (which doesn't really have an English translation, but sounds like "reach") for example, or the Chinese "Chow", "Pung", and "Kong", instead of the more Japanese "Chi", "Pon" and "Kan". It also says "Slam" instead of "Mangan", or any of the other hand value names.

My favorite feature is that when you have declaired riichi, the game will play itself until someone wins, or the game ends in a draw. Auto-discard is nice and speeds up the endgame. It is also nice that the tiles are big on the screen.

I usually play a free flash game, when I want to play single-player Mahjong, but for $1.50, this was a nice purchase.

author: {'steamid': '76561197992856964', 'num_games_owned': 1022, 'num_reviews': 232, 'playtime_forever': 1422, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 421, 'last_played': 1446508081}
review:
A passibly competent 4-player mahjong game, with ridiculously bad translations, zero window dressing*, and absolutely zero explanation of the rules, scoring, fouls, or what the various option toggles do.  Check the forums to see if it will run on your computer first.

*It may look like there will be a dating sim kind of thing, or character dialogue, or bet-to-remove-clothing, but get that out of your head right now.  All this is is hard-as-balls mahjong against the AI, with cardboard cutout girls on the front that you basically never see.  The only dialogue sums up to "I steal the thing", "yay", and "oh no!", all in japanese, and high enough pitch to cut glass or make your roommates think you're watching porn.  You can turn it and the music off.

You can unlock additional AI opponents by winning a lot.  They apparently have different behavior, some being more aggressive than others.  The sliders are not labled, so I don't know what the other two sliders do.

The moment any equivalent mahjong game comes out on steam, I'll be switching to not reccommended.

author: {'steamid': '76561197998956752', 'num_games_owned': 238, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 1001, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 924, 'last_played': 1705703530}
review:
Okay, yes the selling point is the boobs, but I, being ace, get nothing out of them, so I actually bought it for the game. Also this review applies for the school girl version as well, just replace "boobs" with "tiny mini-skirts"

I'm a pretty avid fan of Cantonese-rules mahjong, and this game is pretty similar. However, I cannot recommend this game unless you already have at least a basic understanding of how to play the game - because this game just dumps you in there like a crazed scout leader, and if you don't know what you're doing, you'll lose quickly before you figure out how to play.

The game does toss you a few life-rings here and there, however. It will prompt you if you can call to pick up, or declare preparedness (it makes sense in context), and it will auto-sort. It won't let you move the cards around manually though - most won't mind that, but I, and the guy from Hong Kong who taught me how to play, often depend on doing that, so yeah...

The rules are actually extremely varied too - you can set all sorts of rules, such as your starting bank, what bonus cards are active, and even certain melds and hands. For a simple execution, it's very detailed in its guts.

The camera angle is stupid - set it to over-head or you'll miss what's being discarded - also, you can't ever see the whole table, so you need to move it around - it's not difficult, but it's very annoying to have to continuously do

And yeah, the boobs. ...If the reason you're buying this is to look lewdly at girls, I'd recommend getting something different. Go troll tsumino or something.

author: {'steamid': '76561198078544288', 'num_games_owned': 76, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 142, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 142, 'last_played': 1431902474}
review:
tl;dr version: Don't buy it unless you want the trading cards or know how to play mahjong.




At first I did choose this game because of the tits and it seems like a casual fun game but this is my review:

Pros
-The trading cards have a relatively good market and for a trader it is possible to profit with this game.

Cons:
-Character design is very poor and are all girls and they show the common anime personality you can identify.
-No tutorial.
-It doesn't has a multiplayer.
-Same scenario.
-Repetitive music (not to mention it is bad).

At the end I was like "Ohh this seems to be fun". Bought the game - click on random tiles because no tutorial - watch youtube for tutorial - click on more random tiles - watch longer tutorial - won on 2 place and didn't know why - look for a guide on steam - played GTA V.

But the trading cards are a good market, why? because it has 9 trading cards and all of them are at a relative good price. Anyone can make the badges and the profile backgrounds are good and very expensive some of them so if you buy the game you HAVE to profit with it, otherwise it is not worth to play.

By the other hand if you know how to play mahjong and enjoy to play alone this casual game is worth if and only if it has a discount and this is my final review.

author: {'steamid': '76561198135909646', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 51, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 51, 'last_played': 1430526143}
review: Interesting game but the english translation for the rules and how to play the game has much to be desired, perhaps a revision or maybe a turtorial round or something like that? Only would recommened if you can understand original rules or if you already knew how to play.

author: {'steamid': '76561198013889885', 'num_games_owned': 472, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 487, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 283, 'last_played': 1456778264}
review:
For this game I definitely need [i]meh[/i] button.

Cons:
- [b]Where is multiplayer?![/b]
- Interface is not too smooth. For example you need to move screen if you want to check calls made by your opponents;
- Translation is [b]terrible[/b]. Names of winning configurations (yaku)? Forget it! Of course they translated them into 'English' (for example 1.5 Slam! Yeah! It's obvious what made my eyes bleed) but I recommend switching to Japanese language (save your soul).
- 'Pretty Girls' voices are annoying.
- AI is well... not impressive.
- If you want to learn how to play riichi mahjong this game won't help you at all.

Pros:
- It's riichi mahjong (I guess the only one available at steam localized into English).
- Gameplay is nice, however I needed some time to get used to interface.
- I was afraid it would be mix of mahjong and dating sim. Thank goodness it's not ;) it's just mahjong with some animated girls.
- Girls appear very rarely on screen.
- You can mute all the sounds!
- Each opponent has set different playstyle.
- Mahjong is [url=http://i.imgur.com/NJ2uD11.gif]awesome[/url] ;)

My rating: 7/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198043960246', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 3492, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2839, 'last_played': 1700915055}
review:
Mahjong Pretty Girls Battle is one of the few Riichi Mahjong game on Steam, and on PC in general.

Those familiar with mahjong puzzle games will find Riichi Mahjong quite different from them: rather than a puzzle, this is a competitive tabletop game with very complex rules. This game doesnâ€™t have any kind of tutorial for those new to mahjong, but there are plenty of tutorials and rules guides available on the internet for those interested in learning it.

As someone who only truly learned mahjong over this game I can attest that it is a lot of fun even to those new to mahjong. So if you like mahjong or tabletop games in general, Mahjong Pretty Girls Battle has my full recommendation!

author: {'steamid': '76561198013833495', 'num_games_owned': 185, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 939, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 785, 'last_played': 1431906977}
review:
I think this is a decent japanese style mahjong game. it certainly doesn't have a tutorial so you had better learn how to play from somewhere else on the net.

 also the "pretty girls" part is kind of misleading. there are only 1-3 soundbytes per character, and one cut-in image with i think 2 facial expressions. the girls' art style is consistent, and chara designs are OK looking. not the most beautiful, but not the most ugly.

Also if you are some kind of weird prude, then some of the chara designs might scare you away. but in my opinion all of them are rather tame. Actually if you are the kind of prude that is ignorant of the fun modern popular 2D culture of Japan's nerds, you are probably already making fun of this game and its players and calling it a hentai without knowing anything about mahjong or etc; so oh well why are you reading this on this store page in the first place?

this game looks like it is made by/published by the same people that put out "Nagomi Mahjong" on the iOS and android stores (as well as most likely using the same engine). If this game had online multiplayer, or heck even hot seat multiplayer, it would be a LOT better. For now, this is one of the cheapest (legitimate) ways to buy & play riichi mahjong with a somewhat nice looking 3D tile graphics. [although Nagomi Mahjong was like $3 on the iOS store...]

this game could use more boobs and moe. but i recommend it to anyone that already knows what they're doing and isn't shy of some(rather sterile) cute 2D girls. *goes back to playing Saki Achiga-hen Portable*

none of the girls are as fantastic as Nodocchi by the way.

author: {'steamid': '76561197985926092', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 1585, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1388, 'last_played': 1451811847}
review:
It's crap. 

But it's weirdly charming. 

The translation is laughably bad-- 1.5 Slam!! Humanly Hand!! 25,000 Bones!!-- but it's not too hard to follow. Granted, since I'm already really into mahjong, I could play it even in Japanese. But really, there's no point in buying this game if you're not already really into mahjong. 

That's the crux of it: this game has an incredibly niche appeal. If you're into riichi mahjong, and you like laughing at bad translation, and you like pretty anime girls, then this is the game for you. It's only worth it for the novelty value. Even the girls themselves are pretty laughable, with their utterly ludicrous outfits, but some of them are kind of charming and the voice acting is... something. Though I find myself wishing that they'd just say 'pon' and 'chi' rather than spitting out the same long line over and over again. 

It's as barebones as it comes. It has a good amount of rule options, but it's just 4-player mahjong with 2, 4, or 8 rounds. Moderately challenging, but that's it. It's completely spartan. Nothing else to it. The only thing that makes it even halfway compelling is the staggering requirement for unlocking characters; you have to place 1st a certain amount of times with the one before them in the column, meaning that overall you have to win something like 84 games to get all the non-goddess characters. The Goddesses themselves are much harder, with one requiring you to win with 20 different types of hands, and one requiring you to place 1st a hundred times, though their offensively absurd skimpy outfits limit their appeal. 

Okay, so that doesn't really make it sound very good. Because it isn't. But for all of its bad translation, lack of key features-- yeah, no multiplayer, which makes it utterly pointless as a steam game, /especially/ for the outrageous $15 price tag-- and ridiculous designs, I can't bring myself to hate it. It's just so strange and funny that it's oddly charming. The music's not bad, the art is pretty nice, there's lots of voice acting and what's more, I got a really funny stream out of it. I'm really hoping that this release will pave the way for more mahjong games on steam in the future. 

TL;DR: IF YOU LIKE MAHJONG, PRETTY GIRLS, AND BATTLE, AND YOU DON'T MIND IT BEING RATHER SILLY AND LIGHT ON FEATURES, THEN... WAIT UNTIL IT'S ON SALE.

author: {'steamid': '76561198047068980', 'num_games_owned': 313, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 530, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 375, 'last_played': 1506214094}
review:
I used to think this game is OK and I should be kind to this game cuz J-Mahjong is quite rare.  However I changed my mind after playing several hours. 
First the view is very weird, u need to drag the table to see the mahjong which u chi or pon. 
Second, the AI is stupid, they will chi one and throw out the same one.  I think it is forbidden in many mahjone games I have played before. 
Third, the rule set. Once it was E4 round and I am East, I am the top of the score and I kept winning like 7 rounds, the game didn't end itself! WTF is the rule set, if I am the top and I win at E4, it should be ended whenever I am East or not.
These are some problems I met in the game, I am gonna delete this.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025416072', 'num_games_owned': 1091, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 700, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 165, 'last_played': 1547469093}
review:
I'm enjoying the game a lot. It's a nice Riichi Mahjong game, the only one right now in Steam.
While the translation is a bit lacking, it's nothing serious and don't affect the gameplay.
I'm a begginer at Mahjong, but I don't have troubles to play.

And the characters are a nice plus, of course. Plenty of pretty girls as the title says.
And I must confess that sometimes I feel like in the Saki anime playing this. 

In conclusion, a nice and fun game of real Mahjong.

Update: They added trading cards! A nice touch!! Another plus to the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197969913402', 'num_games_owned': 3553, 'num_reviews': 250, 'playtime_forever': 1464, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 33, 'last_played': 1436137623}
review:
I actually was looking for a mahjong game worth buying.  Unfortunately this is pretty much a tablet/phone app translated to PC and not a whole lot of effort made in the conversion.  If you haven't learned the basics of Mahjong then you're going to be clueless (e.g. Dodger's video on Youtube of this game).  If you have the basics down, you're still kinda playing blind but at least you have an idea of how to win.  

For those who don't know: The game is pretty much like Rummy.  You have to build "melds" that consist of 3 of a kind (Pung), 4 of a kind (Kong) or a run of 3 tiles in sequence (Chow).   So you need 4 sets of melds (Kong, Pung, or Chow) and 1 set of two to win.  The last tile you draw is not discarded and needed to "go out".

You can take tiles from the person to your left to make a "Chow" meld or you can be take from anyone to make a pung or kong meld.  The other players can do the same (naturally) so you really need to be thinking about what you throw away as much as what you take.  There's also a bonus to be earned from NOT taking any tiles from anyone, winning on a self-drawn tile rather than taking from someone else, and also a bonus if you call "riichi" and then win the hand (it's like throwing an extra 1000 points into the pot saying that you're about to win).

I've probably got some of the rules wrong because I'm not a hardcore player, but if you had no idea how to play and you're reading this, you now at least know a bit more.  I hope you bought the game for the mahjong because the characters are pretty bland.  

I learned how to play Mahjong from watching Akagi (an anime) and from playing a few other freebie mahjong games.  While the presentation on this game is better than the freebies in some ways, in other ways it's lacking.

Things that could have made this game better:
[list]
[*]multiplayer
[*]more characters to start with
[*]a basic ruleset to teach beginners
[*]an advanced tutorial to teach intermediate players
[*]an interface that does NOT seem like it was made for tablets or phones.
[*]better voice acting/less annoying voice acting.
[*]a slower pace so you can see what's going on (for the beginners)
[/list]

[h1]TL;DR[/h1]
[code]
That's just a short list of things they could do to improve this.  

Don't buy this if you're not a fan of mahjong.  Even if you ARE a fan of Mahjong, you may want to rethink this.[/code]

author: {'steamid': '76561197998766520', 'num_games_owned': 576, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 282, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 215, 'last_played': 1427130310}
review:
As other people mentioned, if you dont know how to play the game then this is not a good start.

it throws you straight into the game play with no explanation. there is no storyline, no character development, just play and unlock characters.

if you know how to play the game, it just feels pretty darn easy to win.

having said all that I still went through around 3 and a half hours of happily unlocking and relearning mahjong.

author: {'steamid': '76561197963564662', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 75, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 64, 'last_played': 1422511819}
review: I bought the game because it's pretty much the only english translation of Japanese/Chinese majong I've seen (specifically on Steam), and I'm not disappointed. The anime girls are mere window dressing...I would have bought this with or without any additional content. To put it simply; don't buy this if you're looking for porn, but do buy this if you're looking for a real Japanese/Chinese majong experience and already know how to play.

author: {'steamid': '76561197974213308', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 21, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5, 'last_played': 1431185197}
review:
I love how this only works if your date and number format settings match the game's selected language, and how it's totally unplayable otherwise, and how the settings are optimized for a overall mediocre at best user experience if using touch (and totally horrible controls if one uses anything else).

3/10, because it's still kinda possible to actually play mahjong in this game (I didn't test the AI yet, because of the major turnoff bug with the game engine described above, but as it looks and feels exactly like a WP7 game I played two years ago I assume the AI is the same as well, and therefore pretty decent).

author: {'steamid': '76561198006799260', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 434, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 120, 'last_played': 1596216243}
review:
Pros:
- The only riichi (Japanese) mahjong game available on Steam localized into English
- There are different characters, and each CPU comes with a set playstyle. Also, different voices!

Neutral Remarks:
- Only those who already know at least the basic rules of Japanese mahjong can play this game, yet it still translates some of the terms these players should be familiar with into English which IMO puts me off. ALTHOUGH the translations of the winning configurations (yaku) are welcome.
Examples:
[*]Call â†’ [i]Riichi[/i]
[*]Pung â†’ [i]Pon [/i]
[*]Chow â†’ [i]Chi[/i]
[*]Win (appears if you draw the tile) â†’ [i]Agari/Tsumo[/i]
[*]Also the names for Mangan, Haneman, etc.


Cons:
- [b]No multiplayer![/b] â† EMPHASIS ON THIS!
- The interface itself is clunky and not smooth as compared to other games.
- It's missing a lot of features already present in other games (albeit those games are in Japanese):
[*]Showing what tiles you're going to win with
[*]Identifying if a person's tiles are discarded right after draw (tsumogiri)


Essentially, the game is single player mahjong on a PC platform. I don't know about you, but for me playing against CPUs gets considerable boring over time. If you want to practice playing, I guess you could buy this game, but in terms of features, it is a bit pricey (considering there are free web versions of this).

All in all, this feels like an old Japanese mahjong game that has just been ported to Steam. It's lacking features for its price. 

If you're a veteran: just stick with web clients like Tenhou. 
If you're trying to get into this game: I would also recommend the above as you'll probably improve more playing elsewhere.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995711208', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 8257, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 144, 'last_played': 1608475877}
review:
The UI is not fully translated, It mixes English, Chinese, and Jappanese Mahjong tearms in the translation, and the settings use a really strange reverse mouse movment to navigate. If you do not alreay know how to play Mahjong, then you will have some difficulty learning with this game. There is no real tutorial.

That said, the actual Mahjong gameplay is fun and everything works well.

author: {'steamid': '76561198020825802', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 73, 'playtime_forever': 2555, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2170, 'last_played': 1456892231}
review:
Mahjong Pretty Girls Battle is nothing else than a simple japanese version of the Mahjong game.....with anime girls.


For all of you who stayed to read a more "complex" review of this game...well...as complex as you can get about a game of mahjong anyways, here is what you will get.

First of all, the whole mahjong game it self works deceantly, which is good because other than that, there is nothing much really.

The whole anime side of the game, is like a nice sticker on something plain, so you can try and make it look unique. The girls talk in japanese but they all have 3 or 2 lines total, which gets pretty repetitive and the fact that some of the girls sound pretty annoying too, doesnt help either. The music doesn't really fit the whole game either. Thankfully you can mute every sound or the two individually in the options menu if you want to.

Other "minor" problem with the game is that the translation is pretty bad....yeah...never would have thought that I'm  ever going to mention translation issues in a mahjong game...but on the upside, it can make you chuckle for the first time you read it.

Since there is no multiplayer in the game (Which is a real shame) the only thing you can do is to unluck all the different characters in the game, which is just like unlocking different AI behaviours.

One last thing I want to mention is that there is no tutorial in the game. So if you are new to mahjong, this isnt where you wanna start getting in to it, or download a manual from the internet before you hop in to the game.


Overall, the game lacks originality. The girls it self are nothing more than different AI's with different behaviours. It would have been cool if all the girls would have different special moves like I dont know, switching tiles, super mega lucky draws etc. but no unfortunatelly all you have is a basic mahjong game with anime stickers on it.

As for do I recommend it or not, well.....it deppends on why do you want to buy it. If you want a solid mahjong game with  some basic anime skin on it, than yes. This game is good to sit down for an hour and play a few rounds than get back to your life. For people who would want something unique, I would say try and look for one online.

author: {'steamid': '76561198016512142', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 41, 'playtime_forever': 886, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 327, 'last_played': 1428241659}
review:
updated : game got patched pretty quickly and is playable now, the game is still pretty costy for what it offers, but if you were just curious about this mahjong game and don't know enough other people to play it, it does the trick. Now I just need to figure out how to create a winning hand.

I wish it was a bit more poker night like, while simple in premise, offers so much more enjoyment.

[strike]
Well can't really write a review besides the fact that the interface itself isn't very user friendly, there is currently a bug for some people (like me ) that causes the cam to zoom in to close to the board, so all you get to see is some squares. I'll update this review if this gets patched, but untill then I really wouldn't recommend it, unless you feel lucky. [/strike]
